form.longName: PhenX PX230102 - Eating Disorders Examination Adult Interview
form.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorder Examination Â© (EDE) (Edition 17.0D) is a clinical interview assessment of eating disorder psychopathology. The interview includes items related to the respondent behaviors, which are potentially indicative of an eating disorder over the past 4 weeks (28 days).

headerInstruction.text: EEATING DISORDER EXAMINATION (Edition 17.0D) THE INTERVIEW SCHEDULE ORIENTATION TO THE TIME PERIOD What we are going to do is a partially structured interview in which I will ask you about your eating habits and your feelings about your shape,..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: To begin with I should like to get a general picture of your eating habits over the last four weeks. What has been your usual eating pattern? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_eating_pattern)
Have your eating habits varied much from day to day? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_variationto_habit)
Have weekdays differed from weekends? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_weekvsweekend)
Have there been any days when you haven't eaten anything? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_fasting)
Have there been any days between the past 4 to 8 weeks when you haven't eaten anything? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_fasting_monthtwo)
Have there been any days between the past 8 to 12 weeks when you haven't eaten anything? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_fasting_monththree)

What about the previous two months (specify months) ........ Were your eating habits much the same or were they different? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_introduction_eating_pattern_previousmonths)
Over the past 4 weeks, which of these meals or snacks have you eaten regularly during the week? (choose all that apply) (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_patternofeating_meals_week)

validValue.meaningText: Nocturnal snack (i.e., after having been asleep)
validValue.description: Nocturnal snack (i.e., after having been asleep)

validValue.description: Nocturnal snack (i.e., after having been asleep)

validValue.description: Meal or snack eaten on more than half the days (16 to 22 days)

validValue.description: Meal or snack eaten almost every day (23 to 27 days)

validValue.meaningText: Meal or snack eaten every day

question.questionText: PICKING (NIBBLING) (nibbling_230102)

Over the past four weeks have you picked at (nibbled) food between meals and snacks? By "picking" (nibbling) I mean eating in an unplanned and repetitious way. (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_picking_history)
What about when cooking? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_picking_activity)
What have you typically eaten at these times? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_picking_food)
Why would you not call these episodes snacks? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_picking_notsnacks)
Have you known in advance how much you were going to eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_picking_inadvance)
Which rating best describes the number of days on which picking (nibbling) has occurred? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_picking_rating)

validValue.meaningText: Picking (nibbling) on less than half the days (6 to 12 days)
validValue.description: Picking (nibbling) on less than half the days (6 to 12 days)

validValue.meaningText: Picking (nibbling) on half the days (13 to 15 days)
validValue.description: Picking (nibbling) on half the days (13 to 15 days)

validValue.meaningText: Picking (nibbling) on more than half the days (16 to 22 days)
validValue.description: Picking (nibbling) on more than half the days (16 to 22 days)

validValue.meaningText: Picking (nibbling) almost every day (23 to 27 days)
validValue.description: Picking (nibbling) almost every day (23 to 27 days)

question.questionText: RESTRAINT OVER EATING (Restraint subscales) (restraint_overeating_230102)

Over the past four weeks have you been consciously trying to restrict (cut back) the overall amount that you eat, whether or not you have succeeded? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_restraint_history)
What have you been trying to do? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_restraint_details)
Has this been to influence your shape or weight, or to avoid triggering an episode of overeating? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_restraint_shapeweight)

validValue.meaningText: Avoid triggering an episode of overeating
validValue.description: Avoid triggering an episode of overeating

question.questionText: Which rating best describes the number of days on which the participant has consciously attempted to restrict his or her overall food intake (i.e., energy intake), whether or not he or she has succeeded? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_restraint_rating_1)

validValue.meaningText: Attempted to exercise restraint on 1 to 5 days
validValue.description: Attempted to exercise restraint on 1 to 5 days

validValue.description: Attempted to exercise restraint almost every day (23 to 27 days)

validValue.meaningText: Attempted to exercise restraint every day
validValue.description: Attempted to exercise restraint every day

What foods? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_foodavoidance_foods)
Have you been attempting to exclude them altogether? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_foodavoidance_exclusion)

question.questionText: BULIMIC EPISODES AND OTHER EPISODES OF OVEREATING (Diagnostic item). (bulimic_epis_230102)

Different people mean different things by overeating. I would like you to describe any times when you have felt that you have eaten, or might have eaten, too much at one time over the past four weeks. (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_history)
And any times you have felt you have lost control over eating over the past four weeks? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_lossofcontrol)
Have there been any times over the past four weeks when you have felt that you have eaten too much, but others might not agree? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_eatentoomuch)

Have there been any times over the past four weeks when you have felt that you have eaten an ordinary amount of food but others might have regarded you as having overeaten? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_eatentoomuch_others)
Typically what have you eaten at these times? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_food)
Did you view this amount as excessive? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_excessive)
What were the circumstances? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_circumstance)
What were others eating at the time? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_food_others)
Did you have a sense of loss of control at the time? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_lossofcontrol_history)
Did you feel you could have stopped eating once you had started? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_stopeating)
Did you feel you could you have prevented the episode from starting? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bulimicepisodes_discipline)

BINGE EATING DISORDER MODULE(Diagnostic items) (binge_eat_230102)

During these episodes (refer to objective bulimic episodes that are representative of those over the past three months), have you typically eaten much more rapidly than normal? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bingeeatingdisorder_eatrapidly)

During these episodes (refer to objective bulimic episodes that are representative of those over the past three months), have you typically eaten until you have felt uncomfortably full? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bingeeatingdisorder_uncomfortable)

During these episodes (refer to objective bulimic episodes that are representative of those over the past three months), have you typically eaten large amounts of food when you haven't felt physically hungry? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bingeeatingdisorder_nothungry)

During these episodes (refer to objective bulimic episodes that are representative of those over the past three months), have you typically eaten alone because you have felt embarrassed about how much you were eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bingeeatingdisorder_embarrassed)

During these episodes (refer to objective bulimic episodes that are representative of those over the past three months), have you typically felt disgusted with yourself, depressed, or very guilty? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_bingeeatingdisorder_feeldisgusted)

In general, over the past three months how distressed or upset have you felt about these episodes (refer to objective bulimic episodes that are representative of those over the past three months)? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_distressbingeeating)

[Only rate this item if there have been at least 12 objective bulimic episodes over the past three months.] Outside the times when you have lost control over eating ..... (refer to objective and subjective bulimic episodes), ...... how much have you been actually restricting (limiting) the amount that you eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_dietaryrestrictions_amount)

[Only rate this item if there have been at least 12 objective bulimic episodes over the past three months.] What have you eaten on a typical day? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_dietaryrestrictions_typicaldiet)

[Only rate this item if there have been at least 12 objective bulimic episodes over the past three months.] Has this been to influence your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersinterview_dietaryrestrictions_shapeweight)

question.questionText: Scoring: The EDE, and its selfreported versions, EDEQ, generate two types of data. First they provide frequency data on key behavioral features of eating disorders in terms of number of episodes of the behavior and in some instances number of days on which the behavior has occurred. Second, they provide subscales scores reflecting the severity of aspects of the psychopathology of eating disorders. The subscales are Restraint, Eating Concern, Shape Concern and Weight Concern. To obtain a particular subscale score, the ratings for the relevant items (listed below) are added together and the sum divided by the total number of items forming the subscales. If ratings are only available on some items, a score may nevertheless be obtained by dividing the resulting total by the number of rated items so long as more than half the items have been rated. To obtain an overall or "global" score, the four subscales scores are summed and the resulting total divided by the number of subscales (i.e. four). Subscales score are reported as means and standard deviations. (scoring_230102)

Subscale Items: Restraint: 1 Restraint over eating 2 Avoidance of eating 3 Food avoidance 4 Dietary Rules 5 Empty stomach Eating Concern: 7 Preoccupation with food, eating or calories 9 Fear of losing control over eating 19 Eating in secret 21 Social eating 20 Guilt about eating Shape Concern: 6 Flat stomach 8 Preoccupation with shape or weight 23 Importance of shape 10 Fear of weight gain 26 Dissatisfaction with shape 27 Discomfort seeing body 28 Avoidance of exposure 11 Feelings of fatness Weight Concern: 22 Importance of weight 24 Reaction to prescribed weighing 8 Preoccupation with shape or weight 25 Dissatisfaction with weight 12 Desire to lose weight (subscale_230102)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorder Examination Â© (EDE) (Edition 17.0D) is a clinical interview assessment of eating disorder psychopathology. The interview includes items related to the respondent behaviors, which are potentially indicative of an eating disorder over the past 4 weeks (28 days).

form.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorder Examination Â© (EDE) (14th edition) Version 14.3 - Bariatric Surgery Version (EDE-BSV) is a clinical interview assessment of eating disorder psychopathology. The interview includes items related to the respondent behaviors which are potentially indicative of an eating disorder over the past 4 weeks (28 days).

question.questionText: A clinical diagnostic index of +7 or above indicates dumping Indices of 56 indicates subthreshold dumping and should be rated Indices of + 4 or below indicates nondumping. Eructation and vomiting are weighted negatively in order to distinguish dumping from the afferent loop and small stomach syndromes. (diagnostic_dump_230103)
Does the subject suffer any of these other symptoms? (check all the apply) (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dumping_symptomsother)

DIETARY RULES (diet_rules_230103)

Over the past four weeks have you tried to follow certain definite rules regarding your eating for example, a calorie limit, preset quantities of food, or rules about what you should or should not eat or when you should eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dietaryrules_history)
Have there been occasions when you have been aware that you have broken a dietary rule that you have set for yourself? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dietaryrules_brokenrule)
What are these rules? How have you felt about breaking them? OR How would you have felt if you had broken one of your rules? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dietaryrules_details)
Why have you tried to follow them? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dietaryrules_reason)
Have they been designed to influence your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dietaryrules_shapeweight)

Have they been definite rules or general principles? Examples of definite rules would be I must not eat eggs" or "I must not eat cake" whereas you could have the general principle "I should try to eat healthy food". (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_dietaryrules_definiteorgeneral)

When did you first start having regular eating episodes like this, with that I mean, on average, at least two episodes per week over a six month period? That is, what we are trying to determine here, you and I together, is at what age did binge eating become a regular, persistent pattern (which we are viewing as at least two times a week for a minimum of six consecutive months?) (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_bingeeating_ageofonset_firstepisodes)

validValue.meaningText: Binge eating preceded first attempt at dieting
validValue.description: Binge eating preceded first attempt at dieting

question.questionText: Night Eating Questionnaire (night_eatng_230103)
At what age did your weight first became a problem? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_ageweight)
What has been your heaviest weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_heaviestweight)
How hungry are you usually in the morning? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_hungrymorning)
When do you usually eat for the first time? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_firstmeal)
Do you have cravings or urges to eat snacks after supper, but before bedtime? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_aftersupper)
How much control do you have over your eating between supper and bedtime? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_aftersupper_control)
How much of your daily food intake do you consume after suppertime? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_aftersupper_dailyintake)
Are you currently feeling blue or down in the dumps? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_depressed)
When you are feeling blue, is your mood lower in the: (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_depressed_mood)
How often do you have trouble getting to sleep? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_sleeptrouble)
Other than only to use the bathroom, how often do you get up at least once in the middle of the night? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_wakeup)
Do you have cravings or urges to eat snacks when you wake up at night? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_wakeup_cravings)
Do you need to eat in order to get back to sleep when you awake at night? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_eattosleep)
When you get up in the middle of the night, how often do you snack? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_frequency)
When you snack in the middle of the night, how aware are you of your eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_awareness)
How much control do you have over your eating while you are up at night? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_control)
How long have your current difficulties with night eating been going on? Months (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_difficulty_months)
How long have your current difficulties with night eating been going on? Years (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_nighteating_difficulty_years)

question.questionText: IMPORTANCE OF SHAPE (import_shape_230103)

I am now going to ask you a rather complex question you may not have thought about this before. Over the past four weeks has your shape been important in influencing how you feel about (judge, think, evaluate) yourself as a person? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importanceshape_history)

If you imagine the things which influence how you feel about (judge, think, evaluate) yourself such as (your performance at work, being a parent, your marriage, how you get on with other people) and put these things in order of importance, where does your shape fit in? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importanceshape_importance)
If, over the past four weeks, your shape had changed in any way, would this have affected how you felt about yourself? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importanceshape_affect)
Over the past four weeks has it been important to you that your shape does not change? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importanceshape_maintainshape)
Have you been making sure that it does not change? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importanceshape_maintainshape_effort)

Which rating best describes degree of importance the subject has placed on body shape and its position in his or her scheme for selfevaluation 1 month prior? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importanceshape_rating_1)

question.questionText: ACCEPTANCE OF SHAPE AND WEIGHT (accept_wgt_shape_230103)

Over the past four weeks, to what extent have you been able to accept your shape and weight see them as simply being the way you are? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_acceptanceshapeweight_history)
Have you had negative thoughts about your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_acceptanceshapeweight_negativethoughts)

validValue.description: Complete acceptance (viewed as fine; no desire for shape/weight to be different)

question.questionText: NEGATIVE SELFEVALUATION DUE TO SHAPE OR WEIGHT (neg_self_eval_230103)

How long have they lasted? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_negativeselfevaluation_duration)
Have you blamed yourself for being the shape or weight you are? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_negativeselfevaluation_blameyourself)

If you imagine the things which influence how you feel about (judge, think, evaluate) yourself such as (your performance at work, being a parent, your marriage, how you get on with other people) and put these things in order of importance, where does maintaining complete control over your eating fit in? (psychopathologyeatingdisordersbariatric_importancecontrolovereating_importance)

DISCOMFORT ABOUT EXPOSURE (discomfort_exp_230103)

protocol.longName: Eating Disorders Examination - Bariatric Surgery Interview
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorder Examination Â© (EDE) (14<sup>th</sup> edition) Version 14.3 - Bariatric Surgery Version (EDE-BSV) is a clinical interview assessment of eating disorder psychopathology. The interview includes items related to the respondent behaviors which are potentially indicative of an eating disorder over the past 4 weeks (28 days).

form.longName: PhenX PX230104 - Eating Disorders Examination Questionnaire
form.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorders Examination Questionnaire Â© (EDE-Q) is a self-report questionnaire based on the Eating Disorders Examination Interview. The questionnaire based on the Eating Disorders Examination Interview. The questionnaire includes twenty-eight questions related to the respondent behaviors over the past 4 weeks (28 days) which may be indicative of an eating disorder and with height and weight.

headerInstruction.text: Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire Â© (EDEQ 6.0) Instructions: The following questions are concerned with the past four weeks (28 days) only. Please read each question carefully. Please answer all the questions. Thank you.Questions 1 ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. On how many of the past 28 days, have you been deliberately trying to limit the amount of food you eat to influence your shape or weight (whether or not you have succeeded)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_limit_foodinstake_influence_weightshape)

2. On how many of the past 28 days, have you gone for long periods of time (8 waking hours or more) without eating anything at all in order to influence your shape or weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_longperiods_fasting_influence_weightshape)

3. On how many of the past 28 days, have you tried to exclude from your diet any foods that you like in order to influence your shape or weight (whether or not you have succeeded)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_dietaryrestrictions_influence_weightshape)

4. On how many of the past 28 days, have you tried to follow definite rules regarding your eating (for example, a calorie limit) in order to influence your shape or weight (whether or not you have succeeded)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_dietaryrules_influence_weightshape)

5. On how many of the past 28 days, have you had a definite desire to have any empty stomach with the aim of influencing your shape or weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_emptystomach_influence_weightshape)
6. On how many of the past 28 days, have you had a definite desire to have a totally flat stomach? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_desire_flat_stomach)

7. On how many of the past 28 days, has thinking about food, eating, or calories made it very difficult to concentrate on things you are interested in (for example, working, following a conversation, or reading)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_thinkingfoodeating_distraction)

8. On how many of the past 28 days, has thinking about shape or weight made it very difficult to concentrate on things you are interested in (for example, working, following a conversation, or reading)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_thinkingweightshape_distraction)
9. On how many of the past 28 days, have you had a definite fear of losing control over eating? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_fear_losingcontrol_eating)
10. On how many of the past 28 days, have you had a definite fear that you might gain weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_fear_gainweight)
11. On how many of the past 28 days, have you felt fat? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_felt_fat)
12. On how many of the past 28 days, have you had a strong desire to lose weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_desire_lose_weight)
Questions 1318: Please select the appropriate answer to the right. Remember that the questions only refer to the past four weeks (28 days). (q13_18_230104)

13. Over the past four weeks (28 days), how many times have you eaten what other people would regard as an unusually large amount of food (given the circumstances)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_unusualamount)

14. Over the past four weeks (28 days), on how many of these times did you have a sense of having lost control over your eating (at the time that you were eating)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_lossofcontrol_eating)

15. Over the past four weeks (28 days), how many DAYS have such episodes of overeating occurred (i.e., you have eaten an unusually large amount of food and have had a sense of loss of control at the time)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_lossofcontrol_episodes)
16. Over the past four weeks (28 days), how many times have you made yourself sick (vomit) as a means of controlling your shape or weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_control_weightshape_vomit)
17. Over the past four weeks (28 days), how many times have you taken laxatives as a means of controlling your shape or weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_control_weightshape_laxatives)

18. Over the past four weeks (28 days), how many times have you exercised in a "driven" or "compulsive" way as a means of controlling your weight, shape, or amount of fat, or to burn off calories? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_control_weightshape_exercise)

Questions 19 to 21: please select the appropriate answer. Please note that the questions the term "binge eating" means eating what others would regard as an unusually large amount of food for the circumstances, accompanied by a sense of having lost control over eating. (q19_21_230104)
19. Over the past 28 days, on how many days have you eaten in secret (i.e., furtively)? Do not count episodes of binge eating (psychopathologyquestionnaire_eat_secretly)

20. On what proportion of the times that you have eaten have you felt guilty (felt that you've done wrong) because of its effect on your shape or weight? ......Do not count episodes of binge eating (ppq_eat_affect_shape)
21. Over the past 28 days, how concerned have you been about other people seeing you eat? Do not count episodes of binge eating (psychopathologyquestionnaire_others_seeing_you_eat)
Questions 22 to 28: Please select the appropriate answer on the right. Remember that the questions only refer to the past four weeks (28 days). (q22_28_230104)
22. Over the past 28 days, has your weight influenced how you think about (judge) yourself as a person? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_judgeyourself_influence_weight)
23. Over the past 28 days, has your shape influenced how you think about (judge) yourself as a person? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_judgeyourself_influence_shape)

24. Over the past 28 days, how much would it have upset you if you had been asked to weigh yourself once a week (no more, or less, often) for the next four weeks? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_upset_weigh_yourself)
25. Over the past 28 days, how dissatisfied have you been with your weight? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_dissatisfaction_weight)
26. Over the past 28 days, how dissatisfied have you been with your shape? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_dissatisfaction_shape)

27. Over the past 28 days, how uncomfortable have you felt seeing your body (for example, seeing your shape in the mirror, in a shop window reflection, while undressing or taking a bath or shower)? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_uncomfortable_seeing_body)

28. Over the past 28 days, how uncomfortable have you felt about others seeing your shape or figure (for example, in communal changing rooms, when swimming, or wearing tight clothes? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_uncomfortable_others_seeing_body)
What is your weight at present? (please give your best estimate) (psychopathologyquestionnaire_present_weight)
What is your height? (Please give your best estimate) (psychopathologyquestionnaire_present_height)
What is your sex? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_gender)
If female: Over the past threetofour months have you missed any menstrual periods? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_female)
If so, how many? (psychopathologyquestionnaire_missed_menstrual_periods)
Have you been taking the pill"?" (psychopathologyquestionnaire_pill)

Scoring: The EDE, and its selfreported versions, EDEQ, generate two types of data. First they provide frequency data on key behavioral features of eating disorders in terms of number of episodes of the behavior and in some instances number of days on which the behavior has occurred. Second, they provide subscale scores reflecting the severity of aspects of the psychopathology of eating disorders. The subscales are Restraint, Eating Concern, Shape Concern and Weight Concern. To obtain a particular subscale score, the ratings for the relevant items (listed below) are added together and the sum divided by the total number of items forming the subscales. If ratings are only available on some items, a score may nevertheless be obtained by dividing the resulting total by the number of rated items so long as more than half the items have been rated. To obtain an overall or "global" score, the four subscales scores are summed and the resulting total divided by the number of subscales (i.e. four). Subscales score are reported as means and standard deviations. (scoring_230104)
Subscale Items Restraint 1 Restraint over eating 2 Avoidance of eating 3 Food avoidance 4 Dietary Rules 5 Empty stomach (restraint_230104)
Eating Concern 7 Preoccupation with food, eating or calories 9 Fear of losing control over eating 19 Eating in secret 21 Social eating 20 Guilt about eating (eating_concern_230104)

Shape Concern 6 Flat stomach 8 Preoccupation with shape or weight 23 Importance of shape 10 Fear of weight gain 26 Dissatisfaction with shape 27 Discomfort seeing body 28 Avoidance of exposure 11 Feelings of fatness (shape_230104)
Weight Concern 22 Importance of weight 24 Reaction to prescribed weighing 8 Preoccupation with shape or weight 25 Dissatisfaction with weight 12 Desire to lose weight (weight_concern_230104)

form.longName: PhenX PX230301 - Basal Metabolic And Resting Metabolic Rates
form.preferredDefinition: A 30- to 40-minute process (not including the 30-minute rest period required prior to the start of the measure) for measuring basal (BMR) and resting metabolic rates (RMR) using indirect calorimetry, a measure of energy expenditure. By definition, BMR is measured in individuals in a reclining position, upon awakening in the morning after a 12-hour fast under thermoneutral conditions. The postprandial period is relaxed to 2-4 hours and the time of day uncontrolled for RMR measurements. Using an indirect calorimeter, investigators measure the concentrations of oxygen and carbon dioxide in air streams entering and exiting a clear plastic hood placed over the participant's head. Oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production are calculated from the change in concentration and flow rate.

headerInstruction.text: 1. This protocol describes the commonly used metabolic cart equipped with a canopy hood for measurement of BMR or RMR 2. Ensure that the equipment has been properly calibrated at the start of each day. 3. Ensure that the equipment is turned on..TRUNCATED

module.longName: Basal Metabolic And Resting Metabolic Rates
module.preferredDefinition: Basal Metabolic And Resting Metabolic Rates

question.questionText: The technician must remain with the participant monitoring gas flow alarms and visually checking for labored breathing to insure that gas flow does not fail. The participant must remain at rest but not sleep. We recommend that you speak to the participant if you feel it is necessary to keep him/her from falling asleep. If that approach is not effective, then a second attempt could be made by a gentle "nudge." It is important that staff are careful not to startle participants in doing this however as this could cause an increased heart rate, thereby affecting the test. Participant should always be warned verbally in advance of a physical contact. Use of classical music and a relaxing poster over the bed are acceptable methods for keeping participants calm during the indirect calorimetry test. However, please do not use videos or any other strategies for relaxation The participant must not talk, except when necessary to communicate a potential problem. If the participant does talk, lift their arms to scratch an itch, shift their weight to prevent stiffness etc., indicate the time and movement on the printout using a pen or pencil. Confirm that the participant is still thermally comfortable. If the participant has to get up because he/she needs to use the bathroom, then the measurement can be terminated, but the participant will need to start over. The measurement sequence (i.e., steps 313) needs to be repeated beginning with a 10 min rest in place of the 30 min called for in the basic protocol. (instructions_230301)

13. At 30 minutes, check the display data printout for a stable reading (steady state). 14. End the measurement. 15. Obtain the output data from the metabolic cart (time, VO2, VCO2, RQ, Energy Expenditure). Save the readings on a disk or other electronic format. If electronic output not available, staff will enter output onto Excel spreadsheet. 16. Remove the hood from over the participant's head. 17. Ask the participant to sit upright. 18. Help the participants to their feet and be sure that they are steady. Remember that they have fasted and there is a small risk of hypoglycemia. 19. Sanitize the canopy per local procedures. (info_2_230301)

Note: The primary safety concern is that airflow through the hood is maintained while the hood is in place over the participant's head. Loss of flow due to a rare failure of the fan in the metabolic cart or due to a loose hose will cause discomfort and in an extreme case may cause asphyxiation. Although an alarm will sound if the unit does not detect breathing, the metabolic cart technician should remain with the participant throughout the measurement. Care should also be exercised when the participant standsup after the measurement should dizziness develop secondary to the fast. (note_230301)
After the initial 30 minute rest period, measure the resting metabolic rate as per instrument instructions. ______________ (basalandresting_metabolicrates_initial30min_resting)
Obtain the output data from the metabolic cart: Time ____________ (basalandresting_metabolicrates_cartdata_time)
Obtain the output data from the metabolic cart: VO2 ____________ (basalandresting_metabolicrates_cartdata_vo2)
Obtain the output data from the metabolic cart: VCO2 ____________ (basalandresting_metabolicrates_cartdata_vco2)
Obtain the output data from the metabolic cart: RQ ____________ (basalandresting_metabolicrates_cartdata_rq)
Obtain the output data from the metabolic cart: Energy Expenditure ____________ (basalandresting_metabolicrates_cartdata_energyexpenditure)
The printout/electronic record is legible. If not, correct problem and reprint. (basalandresting_metabolicrates_qualitycheck_legible)
RQ Value: _______________ (The average RQ is between 0.75 and 0.9) (basalandresting_metabolicrates_qualitycheck_rqvalue)

Check that the coefficient of variation is less than 10%. Possible explanations are excessive participant movement, irregular breathing pattern, failure to suppress the first 10 min of the measurement, or instrument maintenance problems. If the first 10 min of the measurement were not deleted, manually calculate the average and SD without the first 10 min. If the revised coefficient of variation is less than 10%, record these values. If not, repeat the measurement of resting metabolic rate. (basalandresting_metabolicrates_qualitycheck_coefficient)

PostIndirect Calorimetry Quality Check After completion of the indirect calorimetry test, complete a quality check on the following: 1. The printout/electronic record is legible. If not, correct problem and reprint. 2. The average RQ is between 0.75 and 0.9. Values outside of this range may indicate that the participant fasted longer than 15 h (< 0.75), ate within the last 6 h (>0.93), or hyperventilated during the measurement (>0.93). Other possible explanations are very high fat diets (< 0.75), a weight loss diet (< 0.75) or very high carbohydrate diets (>0.93). If the participant admits to a recent meal, reschedule the test. Check that the coefficient of variation is less than 10%. Possible explanations are excessive participant movement, irregular breathing pattern, failure to suppress the first 10 min of the measurement, or instrument maintenance problems. If the first 10 min of the measurement were not deleted, manually calculate the average and SD without the first 10 min. If the revised coefficient of variation is less than 10%, record these values. If not, epeat the measurement of resting metabolic rate. (post_indirect_info_230301)

form.preferredDefinition: The Three Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ-18) is an 18-item, self-administered questionnaire with Likert-style questions.

question.questionText: 1. When I smell a sizzling steak or juicy piece of meat, I find it very difficult to keep from eating, even if I have just finished a meal. (dietaryrestraint_smellsteak_difficulty_noteating)
2. I deliberately take small helpings as a means of controlling my weight. (dietaryrestraint_deliberately_smallhelpings_controlweight)
3. When I feel anxious, I find myself eating. (dietaryrestraint_feelanxious_findmyselfeating)
4. Sometimes when I start eating, I just can't seem to stop (dietaryrestraint_starteating_cantstop)
5. Being with someone who is eating often makes me hungry enough to eat also. (dietaryrestraint_beingwitheater_makesmehungry)
6. When I feel blue, I often overeat. (dietaryrestraint_feelblue_often_overeat)
7. When I see a real delicacy, I often get so hungry that I have to eat right away. (dietaryrestraint_seedelicacy_sohungry_musteat)
8. I get so hungry that my stomach often seems like a bottomless pit. (dietaryrestraint_often_sohungry_stomach_bottomlesspit)
9. I am always hungry so it is hard for me to stop eating before I finish the food on my plate. (dietaryrestraint_alwayshungry_hard_stopeating_beforefinishfood)
10. When I feel lonely, I console myself by eating. (dietaryrestraint_feellonely_consolemyself_byeating)
11. I consciously hold back at meals in order not to weight gain. (dietaryrestraint_holdback_atmeals_weightgain)
12. I do not eat some foods because they make me fat. (dietaryrestraint_donoteat_somefoods_makemefat)
13. I am always hungry enough to eat at any time. (dietaryrestraint_alwayshungry_enough_toeat)
14. How often do you feel hungry? (dietaryrestraint_howoften_hungry)
15. How frequently do you avoid 'stocking up' on tempting foods? (dietaryrestraint_howfrequently_avoid_stocking_temptingfoods)
16. How likely are you to consciously eat less than you want? (dietaryrestraint_howlikely_consicous_eatless_thanwant)
17. Do you go on eating binges though you are not hungry? (dietaryrestraint_eatingbinges_nothungry)

18. On a scale of 1 to 8, where 1 means no restraint in eating (eating whatever you want, whenever you want it) and 8 means total restraint (constantly limiting food intake and never "giving in") what number would you give yourself? (dietaryrestraint_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 1 no restraint in eating (eating whatever you want, whenever you want it)
validValue.description: 1 no restraint in eating (eating whatever you want, whenever you want it)

validValue.meaningText: 8 total restraint (constantly limiting food intake and never giving in)
validValue.description: 8 total restraint (constantly limiting food intake and never giving in)

question.questionText: Scoring: The 12 scores were coded 1 34 scores were coded 2 56 scores were coded 3 78 scores were coded 4. The cognitive restraint scale was composed of items 2, 11, 12, 15, 16, and 18. The uncontrolled eating scale was composed of items 1, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 13, 14, and 17. The emotional eating scale was composed of items 3, 6, and 10. (scoring_230401)

form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 14 questions with Likert-style responses. The Night Eating QuestionnaireÂ© (NEQ) is self-administered. Scoring methods are included.

question.questionText: 1. How hungry are you usually in the morning? (nighteating_howhungry_morning)
2. When do you usually eat for the first time? (nighteating_wheneat_firsttime)
3. Do you have cravings or urges to eat snacks after supper, but before bedtime? (nighteating_cravings_after_supper)
4. How much control do you have over your eating between supper and bedtime? (nighteating_control_eating_betweensupperbedtime)
5. How much of your daily food intake do you consume after suppertime? (nighteating_howmuch_dailyintake_aftersuppertime)
6. Are you currently feeling blue or down in the dumps? (nighteating_currently_feeling_bluedownindumps)
7. When you are feeling blue, is your mood lower in the: (nighteating_whenfeelingblue_moodlower)
Does your mood does not change during the day (nighteating_whenfeelingblue_moodlower_check)
8. How often do you have trouble getting to sleep (nighteating_howoften_trouble_gettingtosleep)
9. Other than only to use the bathroom, how often do you get up at least once in the middle of the night? (nighteating_getupmiddleofnight_howoften)
10. Do you have cravings or urges ot eat snacks when you wake up at night? (nighteating_cravingsurges_eat_whenup_atnight)
11. Do you need to eat in order to get back to sleep when you awake at night? (nighteating_needtoeat_backtosleep)

13. When you snack in the middle of the night, how aware are you of your eating? (nighteating_middleofnight_howaware_ofeating)
14. How much control do you have over your eating while you are up at night? (nighteating_controlover_eating_upatnight)
15. How long have your current difficulties with night eating been going on? YEARS (nighteating_howlong_difficulties_nighteating_years)
15a. How long have your current difficulties with night eating been going on? MONTHS (nighteating_howlong_difficulties_nighteating_months)
16. Is night eating upsetting you? (nighteating_isit_upsetting_toyou)
17. How much has your night eating affected your life? (nighteating_howmuch_lifeaffected)

SCORING KEY FOR THE NIGHT EATING QUESTIONNAIRE(NEQ) A. Items 1, 4 and 14 are reverse scored. Items 112 and 14 are summed. B. Item 13 is not included in the total score, but is used to rule out the parasomnia, Nocturnal Sleep Related Eating Disorder (NSRED). C. Item 15 is not added to the total score, but instead is used as a descriptor of the course of the symptoms. D. Items 16 and 17 are used to confirm the presence of distress or impairment if NES is present. A score of 25 or greater is suggestive of night eating syndrome, and a score of 30 and above is a strong indicator of NES, but we suggest that the answers are reviewed with the patient in an interview before a firm diagnosis is made. For example, many patients with night eating symptoms overestimate their intake at night. Also, if patients are depressed in the late evening and have trouble falling asleep, but only minimal night eating, this could inflate their scores. (scoring_230601)

form.preferredDefinition: This Metabolomic Studies protocol provides general sample collection recommendations for metabolomic studies giving input on quantity, preparation and handling of a wide variety of specimens. The specimen selection will depend on the experimental design, study aims and tissue accessibility. The protocol also includes the general procedure for cell treatment for metabolomic analysis.

headerInstruction.text: General Sample Collection Recommendations for Metabolomic Studies: Quantity, Preparation and Handling

question.questionText: Blood Plasma and Serum1. Plasma: Collect whole blood in tubes containing EDTA (K2, K3, or Na) as anticoagulant. Extract plasma, cool or freeze immediately, and transfer to appropriately labeled tubes. Freeze as soon as practical, and store frozen. Frozen samples being stored longer than 1 week should be stored at 80Â°C before shipment on dry ice.Serum: Collect whole blood in serum separator tubes and follow tube manufacturer's processing instructions. Extract serum, transfer to appropriately labeled tubes, and store at 80Â°C immediately. Avoid having samples exposed to room temperature for more than 15 minutes.2. Volume 500 ?L is preferable, if available, but we can process as little as 100 ?L. Limiting volume could possibly limit the amounts of requested analysis.3. Samples are to be shipped frozen and on dry ice. Tubes should be clearly labeled with sample identifiers and include a hard copy of the list of samples to accompany the shipment. Please include all available sample information when shipping samples, excluding any patient identifiers.4. Note: As a general sample collection guideline, 1.8 ml of whole blood will yield ~1 mL of plasma. When collecting, it is important to treat all of the samples the same to avoid variation. Materials collected for other experimental work and stored at 80Â°C can be used for metabolomic studies as long as all of the samples were treated the same way during the collection process. Consistency in sample handling is very important. (blood_plasma_231101)

Urine:1. Collect a minimum of 5 mL whole urine (first catch preferred).2. Immediately after collection, place sample at 80Â°C.3. Samples are to be shipped frozen and on dry ice. Tubes should be clearly labeled with sample identifiers and include a hard copy of the list of samples to accompany the shipment. Please include all available sample information when shipping samples, excluding any patient identifiers. (urine_231101)

Saliva: Collect saliva samples in a nonstimulated fashion. Dietary restrictions are not necessary, but food intake should be documented. Instruct research subjects to rinse their mouths vigorously three times with at least 30 mL of water before saliva collection, without brushing their teeth or using any mouthwashes. Five minutes after the water rinse, collect about 3 ml of saliva in a clean plastic container by spitting. Freeze samples as soon as possible and maintain at ?20Â°C for up to one week. Samples stored for more than one week before analysis should be stored at 70Â°C. (saliva_231101)

Tissues:1. For collected solid tissues (e.g. biopsy material), the amount of tissue/sample can vary depending upon study objectives and tissue typetypically, a 100 mg sample will suffice.2. Flashfreeze sample immediately after sectioning and store at 80Â°C until shipped.3. Samples are to be shipped frozen and on dry ice. Tubes should be clearly labeled with sample identifiers and include a hard copy of the list of samples to accompany the shipment. Please include all available sample information when shipping samples, excluding any patient identifiers. (tissues_231101)

Fecal/intestinal samples:1. Collect and weigh 50100mg of fecal, cecal, or chyme samples in a 1.5ml eppendorf tube with sample identification information.2. Immediately store samples frozen at 80Â°C3. Samples should be shipped frozen on dry ice. Please include a hard copy of sample list with all available information in the package. (fecal_231101)

validValue.value: Fecal/intestinal samples: 1. Collect and weigh 50-100mg of fecal, cecal, or chyme samples in a 1.5ml eppendorf tube with sample identification information. 2. Immediately store samples frozen at -80Â°C 3. Samples should be shipped frozen on dry ice. Please include a hard copy of sample list with all available information in the package.
validValue.meaningText: Fecal/intestinal samples: 1. Collect and weigh 50-100mg of fecal, cecal, or chyme samples in a 1.5ml eppendorf tube with sample identification information. 2. Immediately store samples frozen at -80Â°C 3. Samples should be shipped frozen on dry ice. Please include a hard copy of sample list with all available information in the package.
validValue.description: Fecal/intestinal samples: 1. Collect and weigh 50-100mg of fecal, cecal, or chyme samples in a 1.5ml eppendorf tube with sample identification information. 2. Immediately store samples frozen at -80Â°C 3. Samples should be shipped frozen on dry ice. Please include a hard copy of sample list with all available information in the package.

question.questionText: Cultured Cellssee the recommended general procedure below:1. Cultures should be prepared with cells grown as defined per your individual study design.2. Each sample should optimally contain 1 x 107 cells, preferably 35 x 106 cells, and at a minimum 1 x 106 cells. (Cell size will heavily impact this request, smaller the cell size the higher the cell count should be to optimize preparation and requested analysis.) No cell count will be performed on individual samples within our preparation method hence it is preferable that each plate sent to us contains the same amount of cells.3. Remove media as quickly as possible and freeze immediately if destined for metabolomics analyses. Most attached cells may be washed for less than 510 seconds in distilled water or isotonic buffer. See the recommended general procedure below for more details.4. Flashfreeze the plate using liquid nitrogen if possible and store at 80Â°C. Samples are to be shipped frozen on dry ice. Plates should be wrapped in aluminum foil before storage and shipment. Samples should be clearly labeled with sample identifiers and include a hard copy of the list of samples to accompany the shipment. Please include all available sample information when shipping samples, excluding any patient identifiers (cultured_cells_231101)

Recommended general procedure for cell treatment for metabolomic analysis:1. Cell growth and experimental manipulation:a. Plate cells as needed for experiment. Can use individual 100 mm or 60 mm plates. Multi-well plates (e.g., 6-well, 12-well, or 24-well plates) are not recommended since they cannot be quenched (with liquid nitrogen) individually. For untargeted metabolomics analyses, a minimum of 3 replicate plates per group are required; 5 or more are recommended.b. When ready, perform any desired manipulations of experimental factors according to your preferred protocol. If duration of treatment is critical, then stagger the start time for different plates, to allow time to perform the rinse/quench procedure individually on each plate (see section 2)c. Once all experimental manipulations are complete and all needed media for extracellular metabolomics has been harvested, proceed to section 2 for intracellular metabolomics.2. Rinse and quench (preparation for intracellular metabolomics):a. The following steps are easiest carried out outside of a cell hood (the short duration of time ensures that contamination from the non-sterile environment will not significantly affect the cells' metabolome) and close to the incubator.b. Assemble all needed supplies: vacuum aspirator, preferably with tip held by a clamp to allow hands free use, liquid nitrogen in a small hand-held dewar, dry ice in a cooler (preferably with a box to contain sample plates), Deionized water (rinse buffer) in dispenser-top bottle. Generally, our experience is that reasonably robust adherent cells are not harmed by very brief exposure to deionized water. If 5-10 second exposure to deionized water is intolerable for your cells, as an alternative, 150 mM ammonium acetate in water can be used. This salt dissolves to give a solution with a near-neutral pH and is "gentler" on cells than pure water, but it is more mass spectrometer compatible than inorganic saline solu..TRUNCATED(gen_procedure_231101)

Do the following 3 steps (eg) very rapidly, so that the cells are exposed to water or rinse buffer for no more than approx. 5 seconds:e. Add deionized water rinse buffer to plate (either dispense using dispenser top bottle or dump from tube with premeasured volume). Use a volume somewhat greater than the volume of media which was in the plate.f. Aspirate all rinse buffer from plate.g. Set plate on bench top and pour liquid nitrogen directly onto surface of open plate to rapidly freeze cells.h. Once most vigorous bubbling stops but while some liquid nitrogen remains at bottom of wells/plate, transfer plate to cooler with dry ice. Repeat the last 5 steps until all plates are quenched.i. Cover all plates and store at 80Â°C until ready for shipment. This is the preferred procedure to collect and ship samples (keep hard frozen, 80Â°C (steps_231101)
Dietary restrictions are not necessary, but food intake should be documented. (metabalomics_salivatest_food_intake)
Laboratory Results from Plasma test:_______________ (metabalomics_plasma_labresults)
Laboratory Results from whole blood serum test:_______________ (metabalomics_serum_labresults)
Laboratory Results from cultured cells test:_______________ (metabalomics_urine_labresults)
Laboratory Results from Saliva test:_______________ (metabalomics_saliva_labresults)
Laboratory Results from tissue test:_______________ (metabalomics_tissue_labresults)
Laboratory Results from fecal or Intestinal samples test:_______________ (metabalomics_fecalintestinal_labresults)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This Metabolomic Studies protocol provides general sample collection recommendations for metabolomic studies giving input on quantity, preparation and handling of a wide variety of specimens. The specimen selection will depend on the experimental design, study aims and tissue accessibility. The protocol also includes the general procedure for cell treatment for metabolomic analysis.
